facts.text: Football Club Cincinnati was first announced as a United Soccer League franchise on August 12, 2015.
FC Cincinnati began MLS play on March 2, 2019.
FC Cincinnati broke the USL attendance record for a game with 20,497 in attendance against Louisville City FC on April 16, 2016.
The club set a record for the highest attendance at a soccer match in the state of Ohio with 35,061 people for an exhibition game against Crystal Palace on July 16, 2016.
FC Cincinnati hosted their first-ever playoff match in the 2016 USL playoffs against Charleston Battery on October 2, 2016, breaking the playoff and single-game attendance record with 30,187.
On June 14, 2017, FC Cincinnati won their first match against an MLS team, Columbus Crew, during the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup with a score of 1-0.
FC Cincinnati defeated Chicago Fire 3–1 on penalty kicks in the Round of 16 of the Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup on June 28, 2017, with goalkeeper Mitch Hildebrandt stopping three of four penalty kicks.
The attendance of 32,287 for the match against Chicago Fire on June 28, 2017, was the second largest Modern Era crowd in U.S. Open Cup history.
FC Cincinnati set the USL attendance record for a home opener with 25,667 in attendance against Louisville City on April 7, 2018.
On September 29, 2018, FC Cincinnati broke the USL attendance record with 31,478 spectators in a match against Indy Eleven.
FC Cincinnati was awarded the USL regular season championship title in 2018 after clinching the trophy away to Richmond Kickers.
Major League Soccer announced Cincinnati as an expansion team set to join the league in 2019.
FC Cincinnati's move to Major League Soccer was influenced by the presence of their stadium, The Bailey, according to MLS commissioner Don Garber.
TQL Stadium, a 26,000-seat soccer-specific venue for FC Cincinnati, was planned to open in 2021.
Fanendo Adi was signed as FC Cincinnati's first Designated Player in July 2018.
FC Cincinnati selected five players in the MLS expansion draft on December 11, 2018.
FC Cincinnati played their first MLS match on March 3, 2019, against Seattle Sounders FC.
The club's first MLS home opener was a 3-0 win over Portland Timbers on March 17, 2019, before a sellout crowd of 32,350.
FC Cincinnati fired head coach Alan Koch on May 7, 2019, after a 2–7–2 start to the 2019 MLS season.
Ron Jans was hired as head coach of FC Cincinnati on August 8, 2019, but resigned on February 17, 2020, amid an investigation into his alleged use of a racial slur.
Gerard Nijkamp parted ways with FC Cincinnati as general manager on August 6, 2021.
Jaap Stam was relieved of his duties as head coach of FC Cincinnati on September 27, 2021, alongside 2-time interim head coach Yoann Damet and assistant coach Said Bakkati.
FC Cincinnati hired Chris Albright as their general manager on October 4, 2021.
Pat Noonan was officially hired as the head coach of FC Cincinnati on December 14, 2021.
In their first season under the Albright-Noonan regime, FC Cincinnati qualified for their first postseason in 2022, finishing fifth in the East.
Brenner and Brandon Vázquez each scored 18 goals in the regular season for FC Cincinnati in 2022, marking the first time in MLS history teammates achieved this goal tally.
Luciano Acosta contributed 10 goals and a league-leading 19 assists for FC Cincinnati in the 2022 season.
FC Cincinnati's win against Toronto FC on June 21, 2023, tied the MLS record for consecutive home wins in a single season, a record held since 2002 by the San Jose Earthquakes.
FC Cincinnati was the first club to clinch a playoff berth in the 2023 MLS Cup Playoffs on August 30, 2023, with an away win at Atlanta United FC.
On September 23, 2023, FC Cincinnati qualified for the 2024 CONCACAF Champions Cup for the first time with a 3–0 victory against Charlotte FC.
FC Cincinnati won the MLS Supporters' Shield on September 30, 2023, by beating Toronto FC away 3–2.
FC Cincinnati is the second-fastest active expansion club to win the Supporters' Shield, after LAFC who won it in their second season in 2019.
FC Cincinnati played their first ever match in the CONCACAF Champions Cup on February 22, 2024, securing a 2–0 away win at Cavalier FC of Jamaica.
The club was eliminated from the CONCACAF Champions Cup in the Round of 16 by CF Monterrey of Mexico with a 3–1 aggregate score in 2024.
FC Cincinnati played home matches at Nippert Stadium from 2016 through 2020, which underwent a minor renovation in 2016 to accommodate the soccer team.
The "Bailey" was the official supporters section in Nippert Stadium with a capacity of 1,700.
On June 26, 2018, FC Cincinnati announced plans to build a training complex in Milford, Ohio, which was completed by the end of 2019.
TQL Stadium, FC Cincinnati's soccer-specific stadium, began construction in 2019 and was completed in 2021.
FC Cincinnati's first match at TQL Stadium was a 2–3 loss to Inter Miami CF on May 16, 2021.
The primary colors of FC Cincinnati are orange and blue.
FC Cincinnati updated their crest after being accepted as an expansion team to Major League Soccer, maintaining the orange and blue color scheme.
First Financial Bank became FC Cincinnati's exclusive banking and financial services partner in a multiyear deal.
The Incline Collective is the unified body responsible for pooling resources for FC Cincinnati's supporter groups' community events and activities.
The Pride is FC Cincinnati's oldest supporter's group, with satellite chapters in Lexington, Kentucky, and Southeastern Indiana.
Known international fan groups of FC Cincinnati include Kumasinnati in Kumasi, Ghana, and FC Cincinnati France.
The pre-match march to FC Cincinnati's stadium began with the club's debut in the USL and continues to be a tradition with the move to TQL Stadium.
FC Cincinnati's mascot, introduced in 2019, is known as "Gary the Knifey Lion."
The most common nicknames for FC Cincinnati are "The Orange and Blue" and "The Garys."
FC Cincinnati has an in-state MLS rivalry with Columbus Crew, known as the "Hell Is Real Derby."
The "Hell Is Real Derby" between FC Cincinnati and Columbus Crew first gained popularity ahead of a 2017 U.S. Open Cup match.
FC Cincinnati and Louisville City FC competed for the River Cities Cup during FC Cincinnati's USL tenure, in a rivalry known as "The Dirty River Derby."
FC Cincinnati won the River Cities Cup against Louisville City FC in 2016, while Louisville City took it in 2017.
The first-ever meeting between FC Cincinnati and Pittsburgh Riverhounds set a then-USL attendance record of 23,375 on May 14, 2016.
Jeff Berding, former Cincinnati Bengals executive, was promoted to co-CEO of FC Cincinnati in 2022.
Meg Whitman purchased a minority stake in FC Cincinnati in November 2019 and serves as the club's Alternate Governor on the MLS Board of Governors.
FC Cincinnati announced ESPN 1530 as their official radio partner on February 23, 2016.
On March 22, 2017, FC Cincinnati reached a broadcasting agreement with Sinclair Broadcast Group for all home and away games, including playoffs.
The USL reached an agreement with ESPN to make ESPN+ its official live-streaming service on April 12, 2018.
FC Cincinnati broadcast its 2016 friendly against Crystal Palace live on Facebook, featuring special Facebook Live 360-degree footage.
Starting in 2023, all FC Cincinnati matches are available on MLS Season Pass from Apple TV.
FC Cincinnati won the Regular Season Championship in 2018.
FC Cincinnati signed a partnership agreement with Bundesliga club TSG 1899 Hoffenheim on September 25, 2020.
FC Cincinnati operates a reserve team, FC Cincinnati 2, that plays in MLS Next Pro.
FC Cincinnati was awarded an MLS expansion club and started play in 2019.
FC Cincinnati announced a sellout for the Eastern Conference Final against Columbus Crew on March 26, 2024.
FC Cincinnati joined Major League Soccer (MLS) as an expansion team on May 29, 2018.
FC Cincinnati set a USL playoff record for attendance in a post-season loss to Battery on October 2, 2016.
FC Cincinnati ended their final USL home slate with an attendance record on September 30, 2018.
FC Cincinnati signed Fanendo Adi and Fatai Alashe ahead of their MLS move on July 30, 2018.
FC Cincinnati was able to select 5 major league players for their inaugural roster on November 9, 2018.
FC Cincinnati's season opener ended in a 4–1 loss.
FC Cincinnati began playing at Nippert Stadium in 2016 and moved to TQL Stadium in 2021.
The Hell Is Real Derby is a rivalry between FC Cincinnati and Columbus Crew.
The River Cities Cup is a rivalry between FC Cincinnati and Louisville City FC.
Inter Miami CF won the Supporters' Shield in 2024.
FC Cincinnati is part of the MLS Eastern Conference.
FC Cincinnati's head coach is Noonan.
The MLS is Back Tournament is one of the competitions mentioned alongside MLS Cup, All-Star Game, and CONCACAF Champions Cup.
Tampa Bay Mutiny was the first team to win the Supporters' Shield in 1996.
Los Angeles FC won the Supporters' Shield in both 2019 and 2022.
Carl Lindner Jr. and Carl Lindner III are associated with FC Cincinnati, with Carl Lindner Jr. being a notable figure in the club's history.
Adidas became the kit manufacturer for a soccer team in 2019, replacing Nike.
Mercy Health was the shirt sponsor for a soccer team in 2019.
First Financial Bank was the shirt sponsor for a soccer team in 2020.
Kroger has been the shirt sponsor for a soccer team since 2021.
Alec Kann, a player from the USA, is listed as a goalkeeper (GK) with the number 1.
Yūya Kubo from Japan is listed as a forward (FW) with the number 7.
Matt Miazga from the USA is the captain and plays as a defender (DF) with the number 21.
Pat Noonan has been the head coach of a soccer team since December 14, 2021.
Luciano Acosta served as the captain of a soccer team from 2021 to 2024.
In the 2023 MLS season, a team finished 1st in both their conference and overall, with Luciano Acosta being the top goalscorer with 21 goals.
Yuya Kubo has the highest total appearances for a soccer team from 2020 to the present, with 172 appearances.
Luciano Acosta scored a total of 54 goals for a soccer team from 2021 to 2024, making him the top goalscorer in that period.
Brandon Vázquez played for his team from 2020 to 2023, making a total of 43 appearances.
Brenner made a total of 27 appearances for his team from 2021 to 2023.
Danni König made 22 appearances for his team from 2017 to 2018.
Emmanuel Ledesma made 22 appearances for his team from 2018 to 2019.
Álvaro Barreal has made 19 appearances for his team from 2020 to the present.
Yuya Kubo has made 19 appearances for his team from 2020 to the present.
Sean Okoli made 16 appearances for his team in 2016.
Corben Bone made 16 appearances for his team from 2016 to 2019.
Baye Djiby Fall made 16 appearances for his team in 2017.
Roman Celentano has made 38 appearances for his team from 2022 to the present.
Mitch Hildebrandt made 22 appearances for his team from 2016 to 2017.
Spencer Richey made 11 appearances for his team from 2018 to 2021.
Przemysław Tytoń made 11 appearances for his team from 2019 to 2021.
Evan Newton made 9 appearances for his team in 2018.
Kenneth Vermeer made 4 appearances for his team from 2021 to 2022.
Alec Kann has made 3 appearances for his team from 2022 to the present.
Dallas Jaye made 2 appearances for his team from 2016 to 2017.
